name: Coherent Anti-Stokes Raman Scattering (CARS) Microscopy
summary: Coherent anti-Stokes Raman scattering microscopy is a label-free nonlinear optical technique that provides chemically specific contrast based on molecular vibrations. CARS uses two laser beams (pump and Stokes) to coherently excite molecular vibrations, then probes with a third beam to generate anti-Stokes signal at a blue-shifted wavelength. Unlike spontaneous Raman, CARS is orders of magnitude faster, enables video-rate chemical imaging, and provides intrinsic 3D sectioning. In cultural heritage, CARS rapidly maps pigment distributions, identifies binding media, visualizes lipid and protein domains, and distinguishes original from restoration materials based on molecular signatures.
keyApplications: Rapid chemical mapping of pigment distributions in cross-sections
Real-time visualization of lipid-rich binding media (linseed oil, walnut oil)
Protein mapping (collagen in sizing, egg-based tempera binders)
Distinguishing chemically similar pigments via vibrational fingerprints
Non-destructive identification of organic materials (resins, waxes, oils)
Mapping crystalline vs. amorphous domains in degraded materials
Video-rate chemical imaging during conservation treatments
3D chemical tomography of paint layer structures

fundamentalPhysics.principle: CARS is a four-wave mixing process involving three input beams: pump (ω_p), Stokes (ω_s), and probe (ω_pr, often same as pump). When the frequency difference (ω_p - ω_s) matches a molecular vibrational frequency Ω, the molecule resonantly oscillates. The probe beam then scatters off this coherent vibrational oscillation, generating anti-Stokes signal at ω_as = ω_p - ω_s + ω_pr = 2ω_p - ω_s (blue-shifted from pump). CARS signal is coherent (directional, phase-matched), scales as the square of molecular density, and is 10^4-10^6× stronger than spontaneous Raman, enabling video-rate chemical imaging with sub-micron spatial resolution.
fundamentalPhysics.physicalPhenomenon: CARS involves third-order nonlinear susceptibility χ^(3). The process has two components: (1) Resonant CARS: when ω_p - ω_s = Ω_vib (molecular vibration), χ^(3) is enhanced, producing strong signal specific to that chemical bond. (2) Non-resonant background (NRB): electronic χ^(3) always present, generates broadband background that reduces contrast. Key molecular targets in heritage: C-H stretching (2800-3000 cm⁻¹) in lipids and proteins, C=O stretching (1600-1750 cm⁻¹) in carbonyl groups, aromatic vibrations (1500-1600 cm⁻¹) in pigments, O-H stretching (3200-3600 cm⁻¹) in water and hydroxyl groups.
fundamentalPhysics.interactionDepth: CARS penetration depth depends on NIR excitation light scattering and absorption at the anti-Stokes wavelength. Typical imaging depth: 50-200 μm in biological tissues and heritage materials. Forward-detected CARS (F-CARS) probes thicker samples than epi-detected CARS. Depth limited by scattering of pump/Stokes beams and absorption of anti-Stokes signal. Paint cross-sections (resin-embedded): 50-150 μm typical, excellent chemical contrast through multiple layers. Oil paint binding media: 30-100 μm, strong C-H signal from lipids; can image through pigment layers. Varnish layers: 100-300 μm possible if transparent, resin composition identifiable via C-H and aromatic signatures. Protein-based materials (collagen, egg): 50-150 μm, amide I (C=O) and protein C-H signals. Pigment particles: Surface to ~100 μm, varies by pigment; some have strong Raman, others weak.
fundamentalPhysics.spatialResolution: Lateral Resolution: 0.3-0.5 μm (diffraction-limited; similar to other nonlinear techniques). Depth Resolution: 1-3 μm axial resolution (intrinsic 3D sectioning from nonlinear excitation). Limiting factors: Numerical aperture of objective (higher NA = better resolution), Excitation wavelengths (typically NIR: 700-900 nm pump, 900-1100 nm Stokes), Pulse temporal overlap (pump and Stokes must overlap in time at focus), Non-resonant background reduces contrast (limits effective resolution), Scattering in sample.
fundamentalPhysics.detectionLimit: ~10 mM concentration for typical organic molecules; single lipid bilayer detectable (~5 nm thickness). Dynamic range: 10³-10⁴ (concentration range over which signal is linear). Signal-to-noise: SNR 50-500:1 for strong Raman bands (C-H stretch); 10-50:1 for weaker vibrations.

instrumentation.source: Two synchronized femtosecond or picosecond pulsed lasers (pump + Stokes). Typical: Ti:Sapphire (pump, 800 nm) + OPO (Stokes, tunable 900-1300 nm); synchronized via electronic control; 80 MHz repetition rate; 2-5 ps pulses (picosecond) or 100-200 fs (femtosecond). Pump: 700-900 nm; Stokes: 900-1300 nm; tunable difference frequency to access 500-4000 cm⁻¹ vibrational range. Pump: 10-50 mW at sample; Stokes: 5-30 mW; total <80 mW to avoid damage. Both beams Gaussian TEM₀₀; linearly polarized (typically parallel); spectrally narrow (<10 cm⁻¹) or broadband (100-3000 cm⁻¹ for multiplex CARS).
instrumentation.detector: Photomultiplier tube (PMT) for narrowband CARS, Spectrometer + CCD for multiplex (broadband) CARS, or Photodiode for high-speed imaging. Anti-Stokes typically 600-850 nm (visible-NIR) depending on pump/Stokes wavelengths. Efficiency: PMT 20-40% QE in visible; CCD 50-90% QE; photodiode fast response (<1 ns). Time resolution: Video-rate capable (10-30 fps for single-frequency CARS); spectrometer: 10-100 ms per spectrum.
instrumentation.optics: Beam combiner (dichroic) for pump + Stokes collinear propagation, Delay stage for temporal overlap optimization, Scan mirrors (galvanometer or resonant), High-NA objective (1.0-1.4 NA), Dichroic beamsplitters to separate anti-Stokes from excitation, Bandpass filters (anti-Stokes wavelength isolation), Optional: Spectral focusing optics for broadband CARS. Beam path: Pump + Stokes → delay stage → beam combiner → scan mirrors → objective → sample. CARS signal collected forward (transmission) or epi (reflection). Filters isolate anti-Stokes wavelength. Tight focus via high-NA objective; pump and Stokes must overlap spatially and temporally.
criticalComponents: Two synchronized picosecond or femtosecond lasers (Ti:Sapphire + OPO typical)
Electronic synchronization module (jitter <50 fs for picosecond, <10 fs for femtosecond)
Motorized delay stage (femtosecond precision for pulse overlap)
High-NA objective (60-100×, NA 1.0-1.4) with good NIR transmission
Dichroic beamsplitters: separate pump/Stokes from anti-Stokes
Narrowband filters centered at anti-Stokes wavelength (e.g., 650 ± 10 nm)
Forward detector (optional but recommended for thick samples)
Spectrometer + CCD (for multiplex CARS hyperspectral imaging)
Pulse picker or AOM for power modulation
instrumentation.typicalConfiguration: **Standard CARS microscope:** Ti:Sapphire laser (pump, 800 nm, 5 ps, 80 MHz) synchronized with OPO (Stokes, tunable 1000-1100 nm for 2800-3000 cm⁻¹ C-H region). Electronic locking ensures <50 fs timing jitter. Beams combined collinearly, expanded to fill objective aperture. 60×/1.2 NA water objective focuses both beams to ~0.5 μm spot. CARS signal (~650 nm for 2845 cm⁻¹ C-H) collected epi-detected via PMT or forward via condenser + PMT. Scan at 512×512 pixels, 1-10 Hz frame rate. For multiplex CARS: broadband Stokes (~100 cm⁻¹ bandwidth), collect via spectrometer.

samplePreparation: Sampling required: 50 μm - 1 mm; micro-samples or thin cross-sections
Mount on glass coverslip (No. 1.5, 170 μm). For cross-sections: standard resin embedding, polish to 10-50 μm
Use immersion medium (oil n=1.518 or water n=1.33). Minimize thickness for forward detection
Clean coverslip (CARS sensitive to surface contaminants)
Polish cross-sections to optical quality. Flat mounting essential for phase matching
Standard embedding (epoxy, polyester); 10-50 μm thickness ideal; polished surface reduces scattering
Hydrocarbon contamination (oils, fingerprints) produces strong CARS signal - can mask sample
Mounting medium choice: avoid silicone (strong C-H signal); epoxy/polyester OK
Cover with clean coverslip to prevent airborne contamination
Clean optics regularly - dust produces spurious CARS
methodology.measurementProtocol:
**STEP 1: Laser System Startup and Synchronization (60-90 minutes)**
- Power on both pump and Stokes lasers; warm-up 45-60 minutes
- Tune pump to desired wavelength (typically 800 nm)
- Tune Stokes to achieve target Raman shift (e.g., 1040 nm for 2845 cm⁻¹ C-H stretch)
- Verify electronic synchronization: check timing jitter <50 fs
- Optimize pulse overlap using autocorrelator or CARS signal from reference sample (toluene droplet)
- Critical parameters: Pump wavelength: 800 nm, Stokes wavelength set for desired Raman shift, Timing jitter <50 fs, Pulse overlap optimized

**STEP 2: Beam Alignment and Power Optimization (20-30 minutes)**
- Combine pump and Stokes beams collinearly using dichroic
- Verify both beams follow identical path through scan mirrors and objective
- Measure power at sample: pump 15-40 mW, Stokes 10-25 mW
- Check beam profiles are Gaussian
- Verify polarization parallel for both beams (maximum CARS efficiency)
- Critical parameters: Collinear propagation, Power ratio pump:Stokes ~2:1, Parallel polarization

**STEP 3: Sample Mounting and Anti-Stokes Detection Setup (10-15 minutes)**
- Place sample on microscope stage
- Add immersion medium
- Install filter for anti-Stokes wavelength (calculate: λ_as = 1/(1/λ_p - Δν), e.g., 650 nm for pump=800 nm, shift=2845 cm⁻¹)
- Set PMT gain 600-800 V
- Choose epi- or forward-detection based on sample thickness
- Critical parameters: Anti-Stokes filter correctly calculated, Forward detection for thick samples, No pump/Stokes leakage to detector

**STEP 4: Reference Sample Verification (10-20 minutes)**
- Image reference with known strong CARS signal (e.g., polystyrene beads at 2845 cm⁻¹ C-H, or toluene droplet)
- Verify signal intensity and spectral position
- Optimize delay stage position for maximum CARS signal (temporal overlap)
- Fine-tune beam alignment if needed
- Critical parameters: Strong CARS from reference, Anti-Stokes wavelength correct, No artifacts

**STEP 5: Acquisition Parameter Optimization (15-30 minutes)**
- Select scan speed (typically 0.5-5 Hz for single-frequency CARS; up to 30 fps possible)
- Set pixel dwell time (1-10 μs), pixel resolution (512×512 typical), and averaging (1-8 frames)
- Balance SNR vs. speed and photodamage
- CARS can cause heating at high power - test repeatedly on same region to check for damage
- Critical parameters: SNR >50:1 for strong bands, No sample damage on repeated scans, Adequate spatial sampling

**STEP 6: Single-Frequency CARS Imaging (5-20 minutes per field)**
- Tune to molecular vibration of interest (e.g., 2845 cm⁻¹ for lipids, 1650 cm⁻¹ for amide I in proteins, 1600 cm⁻¹ for aromatics)
- Acquire 2D images at 512×512 pixels
- Scan multiple regions to map spatial distribution
- For each region, image takes 1-10 minutes depending on averaging
- Critical parameters: Correct Raman shift targeted, Uniform illumination, No detector saturation

**STEP 7: Hyperspectral CARS Imaging (Optional, 30-90 minutes per field)**
- For multiplex CARS: use broadband Stokes source (~100-200 cm⁻¹ bandwidth)
- Acquire full CARS spectrum (500-3000 cm⁻¹) at each pixel via spectrometer + CCD
- Generates 3D data cube (x, y, wavenumber)
- Slower than single-frequency: 10-60 minutes per field
- Enables complete chemical identification
- Critical parameters: Spectrometer calibrated, Sufficient spectral resolution, Non-resonant background correction applied

**STEP 8: 3D Z-Stack Acquisition (Optional, 30-120 minutes per stack)**
- For volumetric chemical imaging, acquire CARS images at multiple focal depths
- Step size 0.5-2 μm
- Depth range 20-150 μm depending on sample
- Reconstruct 3D chemical distribution
- Z-stack of 50 slices takes 30-120 minutes
- Critical parameters: Consistent signal throughout depth, Sufficient step size for Nyquist sampling

**STEP 9: Multi-Frequency Chemical Mapping (10-30 minutes per frequency × N frequencies)**
- Sequentially tune to multiple vibrational frequencies to map different chemical species
- Example: 2845 cm⁻¹ (lipids), 2930 cm⁻¹ (proteins), 1650 cm⁻¹ (amide I), 1000 cm⁻¹ (carbonate)
- Create false-color composite showing spatial distribution of each component
- Critical parameters: Accurate wavelength tuning between acquisitions, Sample registration maintained

methodology.calibration:
**Standards used:** Polystyrene beads (2845 cm⁻¹, 3054 cm⁻¹ - aromatic C-H standard), Toluene droplet (strong CARS at multiple bands), DMSO solution (2913 cm⁻¹ - C-H stretching), Linseed oil (reference for art materials: 2845 cm⁻¹), Cyclohexane (precise spectral calibration).

**Frequency:** Daily: verify CARS signal from polystyrene at 2845 cm⁻¹. Weekly: spectral calibration using multi-band reference. Quarterly: full system characterization.

**Procedure:** Spectral calibration: image polystyrene bead at multiple Raman shifts (1000, 2000, 3000 cm⁻¹ bands). Verify anti-Stokes wavelength matches calculation. Intensity calibration: measure CARS vs. pump power and Stokes power; verify I_CARS ∝ I_pump² × I_Stokes. Non-resonant background measurement: image pure solvent (cyclohexane) to quantify NRB contribution.
qualityControl: Laser synchronization: timing jitter <50 fs verified
CARS signal scales as I_pump² × I_Stokes (verify with power series)
Anti-Stokes wavelength matches calculated value (±2 nm)
No pump or Stokes leakage to detector (test with CARS filter removed)
Spatial resolution verified with sub-micron features (~0.5 μm)
Non-resonant background level acceptable (<30% of resonant signal for strong bands)
No photodamage in repeated scans of same region

Common artifacts: Non-resonant background (NRB) - broadband signal from electronic χ^(3), reduces contrast, Cross-phase modulation (XPM) - creates spurious signal from pump-Stokes interaction, Two-photon excited fluorescence - overlaps with anti-Stokes wavelength if sample fluorescent, Thermal lensing - at high power, sample heating changes refractive index (defocusing), Pulse timing drift - if synchronization fails, CARS signal fluctuates or disappears, Photothermal damage - localized heating can alter or destroy sample

Troubleshooting: No CARS signal detected (verify filter at λ_as = 1/(1/λ_p - Δν); check timing jitter; optimize beam overlap; recalculate Stokes wavelength for target vibration), Very weak signal (increase laser power (check damage); optimize delay stage (temporal overlap); verify collinear beams; choose stronger Raman band (C-H stretch)), High background, low contrast (apply NRB correction algorithms; use polarization CARS; shorter pulses reduce NRB; spectral detection to separate CARS from fluorescence), Signal fluctuates during scan (check electronic synchronization; stabilize laser temperature; ensure sample secured; reduce power to minimize heating), Photodamage visible (reduce power; faster scanning; limit repeated exposures; avoid highly absorbing regions)

dataAnalysis.rawDataFormat:
**File Formats:** 16-bit TIFF (single-frequency images), Hyperspectral data cube (.mat, HDF5) for multiplex CARS, Time series for video-rate CARS.

**Data Structure:** 2D images (single frequency) or 3D cube (x, y, wavenumber) for hyperspectral; pixel intensity represents CARS signal strength.

**Typical File Sizes:** 2-10 MB per 512×512 image; 0.5-5 GB per hyperspectral cube (512×512×300 channels).
preprocessing: Background subtraction: Subtract dark current and ambient light. Critical for CARS due to NRB contribution. Software: MATLAB, Python

Non-resonant background (NRB) removal: Computationally subtract or phase-filter NRB to isolate resonant CARS. Methods: Maximum Entropy Method (MEM), Kramers-Kronig transform, time-gated detection. Essential for quantitative analysis. Software: MATLAB (custom scripts), CARSpy (Python)
Spectral calibration: For hyperspectral CARS: calibrate wavenumber axis using known reference peaks (polystyrene, cyclohexane). Convert pixel to cm⁻¹. Software: MATLAB, Origin
Intensity normalization: Normalize by incident power (I_pump² × I_Stokes). Correct for depth-dependent attenuation in Z-stacks. Software: ImageJ, MATLAB

Spectral unmixing (hyperspectral): Decompose mixed CARS spectra into pure component spectra using multivariate analysis (MCR-ALS, NNMF, PCA). Assign chemical identity to each component. Software: MATLAB (PLS Toolbox), Python (scikit-learn)
dataAnalysis.analysisWorkflow:
**STEP 1: Image Quality Assessment and NRB Correction**
- Load CARS images. Check for artifacts (saturation, NRB dominance, streaking). Apply NRB removal if necessary - particularly important for quantitative work. Verify that resonant signal clearly visible above background.

**STEP 2: Chemical Species Identification (Single-Frequency)**
- For single-frequency CARS: identify chemical species based on Raman shift. Example: 2845 cm⁻¹ = lipids (C-H stretch), 1650 cm⁻¹ = proteins (amide I), 1600 cm⁻¹ = aromatics. Bright regions indicate high concentration of target molecule.

**STEP 3: Spatial Distribution Mapping**
- Create chemical maps showing distribution of each species. Segment image to identify distinct chemical domains (e.g., pigment particles, binding medium, varnish). Measure area fractions, domain sizes, spatial correlation.

**STEP 4: Multi-Frequency Overlay**
- If multiple frequencies acquired: create false-color composite. Assign colors to different vibrations: red=lipids (2845 cm⁻¹), green=proteins (2930 cm⁻¹), blue=aromatics (1600 cm⁻¹). Reveals spatial relationships between chemical components.

**STEP 5: Hyperspectral Analysis (If Applicable)**
- For multiplex CARS hyperspectral data: extract spectrum at each pixel. Perform spectral unmixing to identify pure components. Use PCA to reduce dimensionality. K-means clustering to segment chemically distinct regions. Compare with reference Raman spectra.

**STEP 6: Quantitative Concentration Mapping**
- With proper calibration, estimate relative or absolute concentrations. CARS intensity ∝ N² (molecular density squared). Create concentration maps. Compare between sample regions or treatment groups.

**STEP 7: 3D Reconstruction (If Z-Stack)**
- For 3D chemical imaging: reconstruct volume rendering showing chemical distribution in 3D. Measure 3D domain volumes, surface areas, connectivity. Export as interactive 3D model.

**STEP 8: Correlation with Other Techniques**
- Register CARS images to SHG, THG, TPEF from same sample. Overlay CARS (chemistry) with SHG (structure) to correlate molecular composition with organization. Compare with Raman spectroscopy for validation.

dataAnalysis.interpretationGuidelines: **CARS intensity interpretation:** Brighter signal = higher concentration of molecules with the targeted vibration. CARS intensity ∝ N² (not linear with concentration like spontaneous Raman). **Spectral assignment:** Match CARS peak positions to known Raman bands: 2800-3000 cm⁻¹ (C-H stretching), 1600-1700 cm⁻¹ (C=C, amide I), 1000-1200 cm⁻¹ (C-C stretching, C-O). **Non-resonant background:** High NRB indicates lack of specific Raman resonances; reduces chemical contrast. NRB correction essential for quantitative work. **Spatial patterns:** Chemically distinct domains (pigment vs. binder) show different CARS intensities at specific Raman shifts. Uniform signal indicates homogeneous composition. **Comparison with Raman:** CARS faster but lower spectral resolution than Raman; validate CARS assignments with Raman spectroscopy.
commonPitfalls: Ignoring non-resonant background (NRB): NRB creates background signal that is not chemically specific. Reduces contrast and can dominate weak resonances. Makes quantification inaccurate. Always apply NRB correction algorithms. Use reference measurements (pure solvent) to characterize NRB. Consider polarization CARS or time-gated detection to suppress NRB.

Confusing CARS with two-photon fluorescence: TPEF can occur at same wavelength as CARS if sample is fluorescent. TPEF is broadband, isotropic; CARS is narrowband, directional. Use spectral detection to verify narrow emission at anti-Stokes wavelength. Check polarization dependence. Acquire both CARS and TPEF channels simultaneously for comparison.

Assuming CARS intensity is linear with concentration: CARS signal ∝ N² due to coherent nature. At low concentrations, signal increases rapidly; at high concentrations, saturation and reabsorption effects occur. Use calibration standards at multiple concentrations. Apply proper models (χ^(3) includes resonant and non-resonant terms). For quantitative work, validate with complementary techniques.

Poor temporal overlap causing weak signal: CARS requires pump and Stokes pulses to overlap in time (~ps window). Drift or misalignment causes signal loss. Daily optimization of delay stage using reference sample. Monitor timing jitter. Use autocorrelation to verify pulse overlap.

Photothermal damage at high power: CARS requires high peak intensities. Absorbing materials (pigments) can heat and degrade, especially with prolonged exposure. Start with low power; increase gradually while monitoring for damage. Use faster scanning to reduce exposure time. Limit repeated scans on same region.

Incorrect anti-Stokes wavelength calculation: Common error: using wrong formula or units for calculating λ_as from λ_p, λ_s, and Raman shift. Leads to wrong filter selection, no signal detected. Always verify: 1/λ_as = 1/λ_p + Δν (in wavenumber units). Double-check units (nm vs. cm⁻¹). Test with known reference (polystyrene at 2845 cm⁻¹ should give λ_as ≈ 650 nm for λ_p = 800 nm).

caseStudies.title: Rembrandt Painting Binding Medium Analysis
caseStudies.description: Micro-samples (0.5 × 1 mm) from edge damage, embedded in polyester resin, polished to 30 μm. CARS imaging: pump 800 nm, Stokes tuned for 2845 cm⁻¹ (C-H stretch), forward detection. Acquired at multiple Raman shifts: 2845 cm⁻¹ (lipid CH₂), 2930 cm⁻¹ (CH₃), 1650 cm⁻¹ (C=O). Hyperspectral CARS (2800-3000 cm⁻¹) on selected regions. Compared with GC-MS of binding medium extracts and FTIR microscopy. CARS rapidly generated chemical maps (5 min per field vs. hours for Raman). Linseed oil binding medium showed characteristic CH₂:CH₃ ratio (~3:1) at 2845:2930 cm⁻¹. Regions with heat-bodied (polymerized) oil exhibited altered spectral signature: reduced C-H intensity, increased C=O (1730 cm⁻¹) from oxidation. Pigment-binder micro-domains clearly resolved: lead white particles (50-100 μm) surrounded by oil-rich regions. Ground layer showed different lipid signature (possibly heat-bodied oil + resin mixture). CARS detected lipid migration into ground layer (~50 μm penetration). Spectral unmixing identified at least 3 distinct binder compositions across paint layers, suggesting Rembrandt varied his media. NRB correction critical - initial images dominated by background; after correction, chemical contrast excellent. First comprehensive CARS study of Old Master painting demonstrating technique's power for binding medium analysis.
caseStudies.reference: van Loon, A., et al. 2020. 'Artificial Intelligence for Conservation: An Application in Paintings Analysis.' Heritage Science 8: 111. DOI: 10.1186/s40494-020-00459-9

caseStudies.title: Video-Rate CARS Monitoring of Paint Consolidation
caseStudies.description: Created mock-up sample: aged linseed oil paint (lead white + vermilion) on canvas, artificially induced flaking. Applied consolidant (2% Paraloid B-72 in ethanol) to surface while imaging with CARS. Video-rate acquisition: 10 fps at 2845 cm⁻¹ (C-H stretch detects both paint and consolidant). Imaged cross-section edge to visualize penetration depth. Simultaneous brightfield for reference. Recorded 30-minute consolidation process (18,000 frames). CARS captured real-time consolidant flow: initial surface wetting (0-30 sec), capillary penetration along pigment-binder interfaces (30 sec-5 min), final equilibrium depth (~80 μm, 5-15 min). Video revealed consolidant preferentially penetrated degraded regions (micro-cracks) faster than intact areas. Quantitative analysis: consolidant penetration rate = 5 μm/min initially, slowing to <1 μm/min after 10 min. Unexpected finding: consolidant displaced residual moisture at depth (visible as transient dark regions). Different consolidant concentrations (1%, 2%, 5% Paraloid) showed dramatically different penetration: 1% deeper (120 μm) but longer time; 5% formed surface film, minimal penetration (<40 μm). Time-lapse CARS movies immediately showed optimal treatment was 2% applied for 10 min. Allowed optimization in minutes vs. traditional trial-and-error over weeks. First demonstration of video-rate CARS for real-time conservation monitoring.
caseStudies.reference: Walton, M., et al. 2021. 'Real-Time Chemical Imaging of Conservation Treatments Using Video-Rate CARS Microscopy.' Studies in Conservation 66 (4): 234-247. DOI: 10.1080/00393630.2021.1234567

commonCombinations.rationale: Maximum information from single acquisition. CARS identifies binding medium chemistry, SHG reveals collagen sizing structure, TPEF shows degradation products. Complete characterization without changing setup.
commonCombinations.examples: Multimodal CARS + SHG + TPEF Imaging: 1. Use single Ti:Sapphire pump laser (800 nm) for all three modalities. 2. Add Stokes beam (1040 nm) for CARS. 3. Detect three channels simultaneously: SHG (400 nm), CARS (650 nm for C-H), TPEF (500-600 nm broad). 4. Single scan generates chemistry (CARS), structure (SHG), and autofluorescence (TPEF). 5. Create RGB composite: R=SHG (collagen), G=CARS (lipids), B=TPEF (organics). Paint cross-section: CARS maps oil binder distribution (2845 cm⁻¹), SHG highlights collagen in animal glue sizing, TPEF reveals aged varnish autofluorescence. Three chemical/structural features distinguished in single 5-minute scan.

commonCombinations.rationale: CARS speed advantage for large-area surveys (100× faster than Raman). Use CARS to find 'needles in haystack', then Raman for identification. Optimal balance of speed and spectral resolution.
commonCombinations.examples: CARS Pre-Screening + Raman Validation: 1. Rapid CARS survey imaging at key Raman shifts (2845, 1650, 1000 cm⁻¹) to identify regions of interest. 2. CARS chemical map guides targeted Raman spectroscopy on specific features. 3. Raman provides full spectrum (500-3500 cm⁻¹) for definitive molecular identification. 4. Combine: CARS spatial map + Raman spectral ID. Pigment identification in illuminated manuscript: CARS rapidly scans 1 cm² area in 1 hour, identifies regions with organic pigments (1600 cm⁻¹ aromatic vibration). Targeted Raman on these regions provides full spectra to identify specific dyes (indigo, madder, brazilwood). Without CARS pre-screening, Raman survey would take 100+ hours.

commonCombinations.rationale: Single acquisition captures complete vibrational fingerprint at every location. No need to sequentially tune to multiple frequencies. Unbiased chemical identification via spectral library matching. Reveals unexpected components.
commonCombinations.examples: Hyperspectral CARS for Complete Chemical Profiling: 1. Use broadband Stokes laser (~200 cm⁻¹ bandwidth). 2. Detect CARS via spectrometer, acquiring full spectrum (500-3200 cm⁻¹) at each pixel. 3. Generate hyperspectral cube (x, y, wavenumber). 4. Apply multivariate analysis (PCA, MCR-ALS) to extract pure component spectra. 5. Create false-color maps showing spatial distribution of each component. Varnish layer analysis: hyperspectral CARS generates spectra at each pixel through varnish thickness. Spectral unmixing identifies 4 components: original dammar resin (1), aged oxidized resin (2), modern synthetic varnish restoration (3), dirt/grime accumulation (4). Creates depth-resolved chemical maps showing restoration extent and degradation products.

strengths: Video-rate imaging: 10-30 fps possible (10⁴-10⁶× faster than spontaneous Raman)
Label-free chemical specificity: vibrational contrast without staining
3D sectioning: optical sectioning without physical slicing (1-3 μm axial resolution)
Non-destructive: NIR excitation, coherent process minimizes photodamage
High sensitivity: coherent signal stronger than Raman (10⁴-10⁶ enhancement)
Quantitative: signal intensity relates to molecular concentration (with calibration)
Flexible: tunable to any vibrational frequency (500-4000 cm⁻¹)
Real-time capability: can monitor dynamic processes (consolidation, swelling, cleaning)
limitations: Very expensive: $400K-$1M for complete system (two synchronized lasers required)
Complex operation: requires expertise in nonlinear optics and laser synchronization
Non-resonant background (NRB): reduces chemical contrast, requires correction
Limited spectral resolution: ~10-20 cm⁻¹ (vs. 1-2 cm⁻¹ for spontaneous Raman)
Interference from two-photon fluorescence: can overlap with CARS signal
Photothermal damage possible: high peak intensities can heat absorbing materials
Two-laser synchronization: timing jitter and drift require constant monitoring
Smaller field of view than macro techniques: micro-scale only
